newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippine court backs Grand Air right to fly.
newsitem.headline: Philippine court backs Grand Air right to fly.

text.p: The Philippine Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld the right of Grand International Airways (GrandAir) to operate an airline over opposition from flag carrier Philippine Airlines (PAL).
PAL had objected to GrandAir's right to run an airline, contending it should first obtain a franchise from Congress.
The court said Congress had delegated the authority to issue operation permits to the Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB), which has approved GrandAir's application.

"Congress, by giving (CAB) the power to issue permits for the operation of domestic transport services, has delegated to the said body the authority to determine the capability and competence of a prospective domestic air transport operator to engage in such venture," the court said in its decision released to media.
GrandAir applied in November 1994 for permit to initially operate the Manila-Cebu, Manila-Davao and turnaround routes.
PAL had opposed the application on grounds that GrandAir did not have a legislative franchise and that there was no urgent need and demand for GrandAir's services.
The CAB rejected PAL's opposition and PAL elevated the case to the Supreme Court.
